Package com.wm.pkg.xslt.extension

Interface IOutputMap

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable
    public interface IOutputMap
extends java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    This interface allows key/value pairs to get accessed from outside a XSLT processor.

    Use method put(Object, Object) within your stylesheet to put key/value pairs into an internal object.

    First, you have to bind the extension functions to their respective Java implementation. To do so you have to declare a namespace corresponding to the output interface:

    <xsl:stylesheet version="1.1" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:IOutputMap="com.wm.pkg.xslt.extension.IOutputMap" ...>
    To invoke this method in the stylesheet use the following syntax:
    <xsl:value-of select="IOutputMap:put($output, '<KEY>', string(<XPATH>))"/>
    where $output is the object itself which must be defined in the stylesheet via
    <xsl:param name="output"/>,
    <KEY> is a name used to identify the value, and <XPATH> is any valid XPATH expression.

    If compiling transformer is used, invoking of the method in the stylesheet should use the following syntax:

    <xsl:value-of select="IOutputMap:put(xsltc:cast('com.wm.pkg.xslt.extension.IOutputMap', $output), '<KEY>', string(<XPATH>))"/>
    where xsltc is the prefix declared for namesace "http://xml.apache.org/xalan/xsltc"

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      java.lang.Object put​(java.lang.Object key, java.lang.Object value)
      Adds a new name/value pair.

    • Method Detail

      • put

        java.lang.Object put​(java.lang.Object key,
                     java.lang.Object value)
              throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException,
                     java.lang.ClassCastException,
                     java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                     java.lang.NullPointerException
        Adds a new name/value pair. If the object previously contained a mapping for this key, the old value is replaced.
        Parameters:
        key - key with which the specified value is to be associated.
        value - value to be associated with the specified key.
        Returns:
        previous value associated with specified key, or null if there was no mapping for key. A null return can also indicate that the map previously associated null with the specified key, if the implementation supports null values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the put operation is not supported by this map.
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if the class of the specified key or value prevents it from being stored in this map.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if some aspect of this key or value prevents it from being stored in this map.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - this map does not permit null keys or values, and the specified key or value is null.
